result.markdown:
--- title: Visualizing Uncertainty subtitle: Lecture 12 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../vizdata-bg.png data-background-size: 800px, cover data-slide-number: none format: revealjs highlight-style: a11y execute: code-link: true warning: true editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- ## Setup {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidymodels) library(colorspace) library(cowplot) library(distributional) library(emmeans) library(gapminder) library(ggdist) library(margins) library(ggtext) library(ggpubr) library(ungeviz) # install_github("wilkelab/ungeviz") # set theme for ggplot2 ggplot2::theme_set(ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 14, base_family = "Myriad Pro")) # set width of code output options(width = 65) # set figure parameters for knitr knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width = 7, # 7" width fig.asp = 0.618, # the golden ratio fig.retina = 3, # dpi multiplier for displaying HTML output on retina fig.align = "center", # center align figures dpi = 300 # higher dpi, sharper image ) ``` ::: # Uncertainty # Playing {.smaller} ![](images/Disappearing_dots.gif){fig-align="center"} Image by Wikimedia user [Jahobr](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Jahobr), released into the public domain. [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Disappearing_dots.gif](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Disappearing_dots.gif){style=".aside"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ # \[Sorry, you lost.\] ðŸ™‚ ------------------------------------------------------------------------ # \[How does that make you feel?\] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## We are bad at judging uncertainty - You had a 10% chance of losing - One in ten playing this game will lost - 90% chance of winning is nowhere near a certain win ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Uncertainty in probability {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Probability distributions ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: Whats the probability that the [blue]{style="color:#378DBD"} party wins the election? ## Probability distributions ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Uncertainty of point estimates ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Uncertainty of point estimates ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Uncertainty of point estimates ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Frequentist interpretation of a confidence interval ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: aside Figure from [Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. O'Reilly, 2019.](https://clauswilke.com/dataviz) ::: ## Everest ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} everest <- read_csv("data/everest.csv") ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} everest ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 21,813 Ã— 21 expedition_id member_id peak_id peak_name year season sex 1 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 2 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 3 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 4 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 5 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 6 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 7 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 8 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 9 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M 10 EVER63101 EVER63101-â€¦ EVER Everest 1963 Spring M # â„¹ 21,803 more rows # â„¹ 14 more variables: age , citizenship , # expedition_role , hired , highpoint_metres , # success , solo , oxygen_used , died , # death_cause , death_height_metres , injured , # injury_type , injury_height_metres ``` ::: ::: ## Highest point reached on Everest in 2019 Includes only climbers and expedition members who **did not** summit ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest-highest-point-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Average height reached relative to:
a male climber who climbed with oxygen, summited, and survived . . . ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Other visualization options: half-eye ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Other visualization options: gradient interval ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Other visualization options: quantile dotplot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Other visualization options: quantile dotplot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Marginal effects: Height reached on Everest Other visualization options: quantile dotplot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/everest_margins6-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R Example: Relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-regressions-1.png){fig-align='center' width=70%} ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R Example: Relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-regressions2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-summary-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Gapminder See [gapminder.org](https://www.gapminder.org/) for fantastic visualizations and up-to-date data ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} gapminder ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1,704 Ã— 6 country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap 1 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.8 8425333 779. 2 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.3 9240934 821. 3 Afghanistan Asia 1962 32.0 10267083 853. 4 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.0 11537966 836. 5 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.1 13079460 740. 6 Afghanistan Asia 1977 38.4 14880372 786. 7 Afghanistan Asia 1982 39.9 12881816 978. 8 Afghanistan Asia 1987 40.8 13867957 852. 9 Afghanistan Asia 1992 41.7 16317921 649. 10 Afghanistan Asia 1997 41.8 22227415 635. # â„¹ 1,694 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 60 Ã— 3 continent year data 1 Asia 1952 2 Asia 1957 3 Asia 1962 4 Asia 1967 5 Asia 1972 6 Asia 1977 7 Asia 1982 8 Asia 1987 9 Asia 1992 10 Asia 1997 # â„¹ 50 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) |> mutate( fit = map(data, ~lm(lifeExp ~ log(gdpPercap), data = .x)) ) lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 60 Ã— 4 continent year data fit 1 Asia 1952 2 Asia 1957 3 Asia 1962 4 Asia 1967 5 Asia 1972 6 Asia 1977 7 Asia 1982 8 Asia 1987 9 Asia 1992 10 Asia 1997 # â„¹ 50 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) |> mutate( fit = map(data, ~lm(lifeExp ~ log(gdpPercap), data = .x)), tidy_out = map(fit, tidy) ) lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 60 Ã— 5 continent year data fit tidy_out 1 Asia 1952 2 Asia 1957 3 Asia 1962 4 Asia 1967 5 Asia 1972 6 Asia 1977 7 Asia 1982 8 Asia 1987 9 Asia 1992 10 Asia 1997 # â„¹ 50 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) |> mutate( fit = map(data, ~lm(lifeExp ~ log(gdpPercap), data = .x)), tidy_out = map(fit, tidy) ) |> unnest(cols = tidy_out) lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 120 Ã— 9 continent year data fit term estimate std.error 1 Asia 1952 (Intercept) 15.8 9.27 2 Asia 1952 log(gdpPerâ€¦ 4.16 1.25 3 Asia 1957 (Intercept) 18.1 9.70 4 Asia 1957 log(gdpPerâ€¦ 4.17 1.28 5 Asia 1962 (Intercept) 16.6 9.52 6 Asia 1962 log(gdpPerâ€¦ 4.59 1.24 7 Asia 1967 (Intercept) 19.8 9.05 8 Asia 1967 log(gdpPerâ€¦ 4.50 1.15 9 Asia 1972 (Intercept) 21.9 8.14 10 Asia 1972 log(gdpPerâ€¦ 4.44 1.01 # â„¹ 110 more rows # â„¹ 2 more variables: statistic , p.value ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) |> mutate( fit = map(data, ~lm(lifeExp ~ log(gdpPercap), data = .x)), tidy_out = map(fit, tidy) ) |> unnest(cols = tidy_out) |> select(-fit, -data) lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 120 Ã— 7 continent year term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 Asia 1952 (Interceâ€¦ 15.8 9.27 1.71 9.78e-2 2 Asia 1952 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.16 1.25 3.33 2.28e-3 3 Asia 1957 (Interceâ€¦ 18.1 9.70 1.86 7.20e-2 4 Asia 1957 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.17 1.28 3.26 2.71e-3 5 Asia 1962 (Interceâ€¦ 16.6 9.52 1.74 9.11e-2 6 Asia 1962 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.59 1.24 3.72 7.94e-4 7 Asia 1967 (Interceâ€¦ 19.8 9.05 2.19 3.64e-2 8 Asia 1967 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.50 1.15 3.90 4.77e-4 9 Asia 1972 (Interceâ€¦ 21.9 8.14 2.69 1.13e-2 10 Asia 1972 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.44 1.01 4.41 1.16e-4 # â„¹ 110 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data <- gapminder |> nest(data = -c(continent, year)) |> mutate( fit = map(data, ~lm(lifeExp ~ log(gdpPercap), data = .x)), tidy_out = map(fit, tidy) ) |> unnest(cols = tidy_out) |> select(-fit, -data) |> filter(term != "(Intercept)", continent != "Oceania") lm_data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 Ã— 7 continent year term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 Asia 1952 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.16 1.25 3.33 2.28e-3 2 Asia 1957 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.17 1.28 3.26 2.71e-3 3 Asia 1962 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.59 1.24 3.72 7.94e-4 4 Asia 1967 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.50 1.15 3.90 4.77e-4 5 Asia 1972 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.44 1.01 4.41 1.16e-4 6 Asia 1977 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.87 1.03 4.75 4.42e-5 7 Asia 1982 log(gdpPâ€¦ 4.78 0.852 5.61 3.77e-6 8 Asia 1987 log(gdpPâ€¦ 5.17 0.727 7.12 5.31e-8 9 Asia 1992 log(gdpPâ€¦ 5.09 0.649 7.84 7.60e-9 10 Asia 1997 log(gdpPâ€¦ 5.11 0.628 8.15 3.35e-9 # â„¹ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Making a plot with error bars in R {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(lm_data) + aes( x = year, y = estimate, ymin = estimate - 1.96*std.error, ymax = estimate + 1.96*std.error, color = continent ) + geom_pointrange( position = position_dodge(width = 1) ) + scale_x_continuous( breaks = gapminder |> distinct(year) |> pull(year) ) + theme(legend.position = "top") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-model-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: aside Figure and code idea from [Kieran Healy. Data Visualization: A practical introduction. Princeton University Press, 2019.](https://socviz.co/) ::: ## Data prep For 1952 only: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_data_1952 <- lm_data |> filter(year == 1952) |> mutate( continent = fct_reorder(continent, estimate) ) ``` ::: ## Half-eye {.smaller} `ggdist::stat_dist_halfeye()`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3-10"} lm_data_1952 |> ggplot(aes(x = estimate, y = continent)) + stat_dist_halfeye( aes( dist = dist_normal( mu = estimate, sigma = std.error ) ), point_size = 4 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-halfeye-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Gradient interval {.smaller} `ggdist::stat_dist_gradientinterval()`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3-11"} lm_data_1952 |> ggplot(aes(x = estimate, y = continent)) + stat_dist_gradientinterval( aes( dist = dist_normal( mu = estimate, sigma = std.error ) ), point_size = 4, fill = "skyblue" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-gradinterval-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Dots interval {.smaller} `ggdist::stat_dist_dotsinterval()`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3-12"} lm_data_1952 |> ggplot(aes(x = estimate, y = continent)) + stat_dist_dotsinterval( aes( dist = dist_normal( mu = estimate, sigma = std.error ) ), point_size = 4, fill = "skyblue", quantiles = 20 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-quantiledots-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Dots interval {.smaller} `ggdist::stat_dist_dotsinterval()`: ::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|11"} lm_data_1952 |> ggplot(aes(x = estimate, y = continent)) + stat_dist_dotsinterval( aes( dist = dist_normal( mu = estimate, sigma = std.error ) ), point_size = 4, fill = "skyblue", quantiles = 10 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12-visualizing-uncertainty_files/figure-revealjs/gapminder-quantiledots2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Further reading and acknowledgements {.smaller} - Acknowledgements: Slides from [Visualizing uncertainty](https://wilkelab.org/SDS375/slides/visualizing-uncertainty.html) by Claus Wilke - Further reading - Fundamentals of Data Visualization: [Chapter 16: Visualizing uncertainty](https://clauswilke.com/dataviz/visualizing-uncertainty.html) - Data Visualization---A Practical Introduction: [Chapter 6.6: Grouped analysis and list columns](https://socviz.co/modeling.html#grouped-analysis-and-list-columns) - Data Visualization---A Practical Introduction: [Chapter 6.7: Plot marginal effects](https://socviz.co/modeling.html#plot-marginal-effects) - **ggdist** reference documentation: https://mjskay.github.io/ggdist/index.html - **ggdist** vignette: [Frequentist uncertainty visualization](https://mjskay.github.io/ggdist/articles/freq-uncertainty-vis.html)

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
